commit_message:
Add a new option '--redirect-http-code' into L7Policy CLI

This patch add a new option '--redirect-http-code' into L7Policy for
redirection url and prefix action.

Change-Id: I30b1a7555e1d910e07379bc69e739225a35a1a0c
Story: 2003609
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/625007

[{'created': '2019-02-27 10:46:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix sfc-tempest-dsvm

Instead of allowing all api extensions, just allow extensions which are
supported in Pike

Change-Id: I435f6e6c04d4e73bdad8cac7a7a195be440f9437
Signed-off-by: Manuel Buil <mbuil@suse.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-03-04 22:40:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix gates

py35: Fix an issue where toxenv fails when it encounters a non-empty
__pycache__ directory. This adjusts the options passed to find so that it is
tolerant ofthis scenario and allows tox runs to proceed.

sphinx-docs: Cover the case where no packages must be installed

functional-dsvm: Fix post gate hook to accommodate for new os-testr
New versions now use .stestr instead of previous .testrepository
directory

sfc-tempest-dsvm: Instead of allowing all api extensions, just allow extensions
which are supported in Pike

Change-Id: I435f6e6c04d4e73bdad8cac7a7a195be440f9437
Signed-off-by: Manuel Buil <mbuil@suse.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix gates

py35: Fix an issue where toxenv fails when it encounters a non-empty
__pycache__ directory. This adjusts the options passed to find so that it is
tolerant ofthis scenario and allows tox runs to proceed.

sphinx-docs: Cover the case where no packages must be installed

functional-dsvm: Fix post gate hook to accommodate for new os-testr
New versions now use .stestr instead of previous .testrepository
directory

sfc-tempest-dsvm: Instead of allowing all api extensions, just allow extensions
which are supported in Pike

Change-Id: I435f6e6c04d4e73bdad8cac7a7a195be440f9437
Signed-off-by: Manuel Buil <mbuil@suse.com>

[{'created': '2019-03-04 16:39:04.000000000', 'message': "Consistent HTTPS for URLs in non-historical files

Update the URLs in various templates and generated content to
consistently use https:// instead of a mix of that and http://, and
while we're at it set the homepage for the Python package of this
repo to the election site rather than the OpenStack Foundation site.

Change-Id: I4fa53076ed9bcdf1545d9c4aa5e80dc5dad95210
"}]
commit_message:
Consistent HTTPS for URLs in non-historical files

Update the URLs in various templates and generated content to
consistently use https:// instead of a mix of that and http://, and
while we're at it set the homepage for the Python package of this
repo to the election site rather than the OpenStack Foundation site.

Change-Id: I4fa53076ed9bcdf1545d9c4aa5e80dc5dad95210

commit_message:
Move syncpoint from DB to ETCD

Switch Syncpoint backend from DB to ETCD.
Change RPC API version to new version, so old and new
engines will not mix up.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/569582

Change-Id: I707301c410779df473513803a2efaa62b1a20578

[{'created': '2018-04-03 06:24:42.000000000', 'message': "Move Stack Lock from DB to Etcd

Switch Stack Lock backend from DB to Etcd
Bump RPC API Version so old engine won't use this feature during

commit_message:
Move Stack Lock from DB to Etcd

Switch Stack Lock backend from DB to Etcd
Bump RPC API Version so old engine won't use this feature during
rolling upgrade.

Change-Id: If49db14e7d7b9baa6239cb212a5ca0fc4b34be1a

Support Etcd

Add etcd base infrastructure to heat.
Add basic etcd module and config options
Add config options to devstack.
Add fake etcd backend to HeatTestCase

still presented.

commit_message:
Document fileystem drv chunk size option

A new config option has been added to the filesystem driver
which allows specifying the chunk size to be used.

This change mentions it in the config documentation.

Depends-On: I1559c03308d36ecf9305c7a72ad658ecd1f2dc76

Change-Id: I4ddce9c3ed8f393f76a4c81879c68a3cfcf68bbf

subject: Refresh extended in-use volumes
messages:
[{'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2017-11-14 16:55:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2017-11-21 10:20:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Very simple implementation. The os-brick code for this merged about 2 years ago.'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2017-11-21 11:11:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-03-05 19:39:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Why don't you guys upstream this?"}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2019-03-06 05:39:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Matt: thanks for your interest in this, it's indeed a simple change that should be easy to merge upstream.

To be honest, having an out-of-tree driver worked better for us, allowing us to move at a faster pace.

We did try to keep the upstream driver in sync but it was falling behind too much. Some patches didn't get reviews in months, even years and we couldn't wait that long. For this reason, we decided to have just critical bug fixes upstream, keeping the rest downstream.

I think some people may avoid reviewing Hyper-V driver patches either because they aren't familiar enough with the code, it's not relevant to them or because they are asked to focus on the libvirt driver and Nova core functionality, which I really do understand.

Nevertheless, it may be a good moment to update the upstream driver. I'd say OpenStack reached a certain degree of maturity that things aren't changing as much as they used to.

Reducing the code base differences between the two would allow also allow us to port patches more easily. I'd probably avoid a large patch called "Resync Hyper-V driver" but having dozens of small patches wouldn't help either.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-14 16:55:50.000000000', 'message': "Refresh extended in-use volumes

This change enables the 'supports_extend_volume' driver capability,
updating cached information about already extended in-use volumes.

Note that this will only work with passthrough disks (iSCSI/FC) for
the moment. Also, this only refreshes host side disk information,
a rescan is required on the guest side as well.

Change-Id: Ic4ba9e0c2ed5bcd443fa8eaffac06752a97b0103
Implements: blueprint hyperv-extend-volume
"}]
commit_message:
Refresh extended in-use volumes

This change enables the 'supports_extend_volume' driver capability,
updating cached information about already extended in-use volumes.

Note that this will only work with passthrough disks (iSCSI/FC) for
the moment. Also, this only refreshes host side disk information,
a rescan is required on the guest side as well.

Change-Id: Ic4ba9e0c2ed5bcd443fa8eaffac06752a97b0103
Implements: blueprint hyperv-extend-volume

commit_message:
Ceilometer chart: Add missing definition files

This commit adds two missing definition files which are
meters.yaml and polling.yaml.

meters.yaml is the meter definition file that used for
ceilometer notification agent to convert meters.
polling.yaml is the polling definition file that used for
ceilometer polling agents to pull meters.

Change-Id: I6b9b7543aa1a77661d6a86166af59fde85085513
Story: 2005019
Task: 29811
Signed-off-by: Angie Wang <angie.wang@windriver.com>

commit_message:
Deprecate docker runtime

The plan is to deprecate it in Stein and remove it in Train.
Podman is now the default.

commit_message:
Ceilometer chart: replace the obsolete ceilometer upgrade command

The current ceilometer upgrade command "ceilometer-dbsync" was
deprecated since newton and was removed since ocata. The commit
updates to use the replaced command.

Story: 2005019
Task: 29727
Change-Id: I06afb2cc99726991d6941aabb039379dc78c5d66
Signed-off-by: Angie Wang <angie.wang@windriver.com>

It seems like this might be more of a regression test than something that users are going to use to validate their cloud, and thus would make more sense in the Heat repo itself?

commit_message:
Drop py35 jobs

Python 3.5 was the target runtime for the Rocky release. The current
target py3 runtime for Stein is Python 3.6, so there is no reason to
keep testing against the older version.

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html#python-runtime-for-stein

Change-Id: Ib7804441fb3608b955c642014620fcab39d911ef

Looks good to me!'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-07-17 07:17:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I commented on bug about idea and background of making all the identity admin tests to force using dynamic cred [1].

This is get tests and i agree on the changes. I am ok once we move this tests to non admin dir. 

[1]
"Agree on not forcing the dynamic cred on tests which does not change the test account like GET etc.

Disagree on removing the forcing of dynamic cred for tests which are changing the test account in some extend. Changing the test cred can effect the other tests execution as same cred are shared among other tests when using pre provisioned accounts. That was the main reason to making all the identity admin tests to use force_tenant_isolation by default.

So this bug is valid and we will go case by case and evaluate the above criteria to decide whether we can remove the force_tenant_isolation from identity tests. I will review the proposed patches."'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-07-17 07:17:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
no force_tenant_isolation in DefaultDomainTestJSON

No need for dynamic credentials to test showing the default domain.

By setting this value to False, consumers with an immutable user source
can execute this test.

Depends-On: I83a9b8af775580d36a1141be55e9c1cc283a75b6
Partial-Bug: #1714277
Change-Id: Ib85691ae3f7b5a4d4a9da620b6ec46c44380ef03

Check defined networks in the resource registry of the stack against the
networks defined in the environment files. If the environment provided
doesn't have the networks defined, it's likely they were improperly
dropped which can lead to deployment issues. This is a light check that
only checks for the existance of the networks but not the contents of
those networks. This handles the case where a user forgets to include
the network-isolation configuration on a subsequent update to the cloud.

Partial-Bug: #1817631
Change-Id: Ia97a2367770e37bf8c55f2fd04c9a9efde914a67

"}]
commit_message:
Check that the networks are defined on update

Check defined networks in the resource registry of the stack against the
networks defined in the environment files. If the environment provided
doesn't have the networks defined, it's likely they were improperly
dropped which can lead to deployment issues. This is a light check that
only checks for the existance of the networks but not the contents of
those networks. This handles the case where a user forgets to include
the network-isolation configuration on a subsequent update to the cloud.
This does not prevent a user from changing the contents of the networks
to something that breaks their deployment.

Conflicts:
	tripleoclient/tests/v1/overcloud_deploy/test_overcloud_deploy.py

Partial-Bug: #1817631
Change-Id: Ia97a2367770e37bf8c55f2fd04c9a9efde914a67
(cherry picked from commit 1a71c441fa8958896d7f380636075612c67bf7da)
(cherry picked from commit ab72340021351a82e51920d56ec2247ac265df08)

(2 comments)

I think we may not be guarding sufficiently the paths into the DHSS=True back ends that haven't implemented manage/unmanage shares and share servers with multi-tenancy yet.  But I'll look at this again tomorrow.

Just want to log the concern."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-02-26 14:46:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Overall this looks good but I think we're just going to pass manage/unmanage calls through to all DHSS=True back ends, even those that don't have the capability to deal with these yet like generic, Huawei, EMC.  unmanage calls may just work :)   I was able to unmanage generic driver shares and share servers running in DHSS=True mode with this code.  But manage share server will fail with Unimplemented method from the driver if it doesn't get hung up in the network allocation code earlier.  And manage share *will* be implemented in the driver but not written for the DHSS=True case -- e.g. generic driver will attempt to use the "common server."

I'm not sure of the best way to deal with this issue.  One idea would be to add a configuration option for DHSS=True back ends that have this support and a corresponding column in the share server table.  That way the api could check that column for the relevant share server and indicate lack of support right away rather than calling all the way down into the driver and failing there or (in the case of unmanage) perhaps mysteriously succeeding.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-26 18:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-26 18:36:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-26 18:38:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

(2 comments)

Hi Tom. I addressed some of your comments. Regarding blocking manage/unmanage calls from affecting DHSS=True backends that do not support this feature, from my understanding this shouldn't need to be done because this is the same case as manage/unmanage shares/snapshots. They are Admin APIs, and similarly in DHSS=False, if a given backend does not support it, we don't do anything."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-02-26 19:33:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> Regarding blocking manage/unmanage calls from affecting DHSS=True backends that do not support this feature, from my understanding this shouldn't need to be done because this is the same case as manage/unmanage shares/snapshots. They are Admin APIs, and similarly in DHSS=False, if a given backend does not support it, we don't do anything.

OK, I guess that's a good argument for not catching these cases in the API but there is still a difference here with the current manange/unmanage cases.  If a driver doesn't implement manage they will get a NotImplemented error, whereas in this case the driver's method will be called and whether damage will be done or not depends on the driver."}, {'account_id': 21863, 'date': '2019-02-26 19:34:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Build succeeded.

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-26 20:27:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(6 comments)

Regarding "If a driver doesn't implement manage they will get a NotImplemented error, whereas in this case the driver's method will be called and whether damage will be done or not depends on the driver."

Hmm Not really. Looking at the driver.py interface, Manage, manage-snapshot, manage-server, and get_share_server_network_info all raise NotImplementedError if the driver doesn't do anything. Unmanage, Unmanage-snapshot, and unmanaging share server (no driver interface), don't raise exceptions and succeed regardless of the driver doing anything. So, if there is any damage done, it is the same as the existing features.

Indeed, if a driver chooses to implement the feature, it has to support it. If a driver doesn't implement it, it can be unmanaged but not managed back (as previous features). Attempting to manage a share server without the driver implementation does no damage, the network allocations aren't touched, just validated.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-26 20:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/manage-unmanage-with-share-servers to manage-unmanage-with-share-servers'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-02-26 22:04:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

(4 comments)

On the point of contention I'm going to think overnight before I respond :)

This is looking pretty good though, and thanks for the other explanations and clarifications."}, {'account_id': 20695, 'date': '2019-02-26 22:31:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

* nexenta-manila_ns5_nfs http://140.174.232.106/refs-changes-31-635831-14/manila_ns5_nfs : SUCCESS in 69m 42s'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-27 01:48:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Published edit on patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 21863, 'date': '2019-02-27 02:09:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

- dsvm-tempest-infinibox-nfs http://openstack-ci-logs.aws.infinidat.com/31/635831/15/check/dsvm-tempest-infinibox-nfs/419b90f : FAILURE in 21m 09s"}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-02-27 12:57:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

(1 comment)

> Looking at the driver.py interface, Manage, manage-snapshot, manage-server, and get_share_server_network_info all raise NotImplementedError if the driver doesn't do anything. Unmanage, Unmanage-snapshot, and unmanaging share server (no driver interface), don't raise exceptions and succeed regardless of the driver doing anything. So, if there is any damage done, it is the same as the existing features.

It's different in an important way for DHSS=True back ends that already implement manage for DHSS=False.  The admin won't get a NotImplemented error but the back end will not be coded to do the right thing for DHSS=True and will break in unpredictable ways.  As an example, the generic driver will attempt to manage the share using the common share server that it uses when managing shares in the DHSS=False case rather than the share server that was specified in the manage share command."}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-27 14:31:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Published edit on patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-27 14:44:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17: Patch Set 16 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-02-27 15:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

@Tom, I understand the concern now.

What if we create a new driver interfaces for each method (manage_share_with_server,manage_snapshot_with_server, etc) and then, by default, no driver will have implemented it, and if a vendor wants to, the implementation may be as simple as invokeing self.manage_existing, self.manage_existing_snapshot?'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-02-27 15:54:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

@ganso: I *think* that would be sufficient.  Want to get some other reviewers on this though.  This is an important patch and good work so it deserves thorough review.'}, {'account_id': 21863, 'date': '2019-02-27 16:06:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-08 13:03:25.000000000', 'message': 'Add manage/unmanage of shares in DHSS=True

This patch adds Manage/Unmanage of share servers in
Manila. It also updates the Manage Share API to accept
a "share_server_id" parameter, and updates Unmanage
of Share and Snapshots API to allow unmanaging of
shares and snapshots in DHSS=True.

Managed share servers are not deleted automatically
by manila, and if a single share is unmanaged in
DHSS=True, the respective share server will not be
deleted automatically as well.

Managing share servers require that the driver
implements 2 functions:
- get_share_server_network_info: obtain IPs from
  share server.
- manage_server: perform required operations to
  manage and return dict of backend_details.

The IPs obtained from the backend are validated
by the Network plugin, so ports with the exact
IPs must exist in the subnet and admin subnet
associated with the share network specified
when managing the share server (unless
StandaloneNetworkPlugin is used).

It is recommended to rename the backend resource
if possible when managing the share server, to
easily allow this feature to be tested in the CI.

This patch bumps the API microversion to 2.49.

APIImpact
DocImpact

Change-Id: I108961e7436ba13550ef2b8f02079c6e599a6166

DHSS=True, the respective share server will not be
deleted automatically as well.

Managing share servers require that the driver
implements 2 functions:
- get_share_server_network_info: obtain IPs from
  share server.
- manage_server: perform required operations to
  manage and return dict of backend_details.

The IPs obtained from the backend are validated
by the Network plugin, so ports with the exact
IPs must exist in the subnet and admin subnet
associated with the share network specified
when managing the share server (unless
StandaloneNetworkPlugin is used).

It is recommended to rename the backend resource
if possible when managing the share server, to
easily allow this feature to be tested in the CI.

This patch bumps the API microversion to 2.49.

'}, {'created': '2019-03-03 21:07:15.000000000', 'message': 'Add manage/unmanage of shares in DHSS=True

This patch adds Manage/Unmanage of share servers in
Manila. It also updates the Manage Share API to accept
a "share_server_id" parameter, and updates Unmanage
of Share and Snapshots API to allow unmanaging of
shares and snapshots in DHSS=True.

Managed share servers are not deleted automatically
by manila, and if a single share is unmanaged in
DHSS=True, the respective share server will not be
deleted automatically as well.

Managing share servers require that the driver
implements 2 functions:
- get_share_server_network_info: obtain IPs from
  share server.
- manage_server: perform required operations to
  manage and return dict of backend_details.

Unmanaging share servers require that the driver
overrides unmanage_server function.

The IPs obtained from the backend are validated
by the Network plugin, so ports with the exact
IPs must exist in the subnet and admin subnet
associated with the share network specified
when managing the share server (unless
StandaloneNetworkPlugin is used).

It is recommended to rename the backend resource
if possible when managing the share server, to
prevent issues with re-managing a share server
that has already been managed.

This patch bumps the API microversion to 2.49.

commit_message:
Add manage/unmanage of shares in DHSS=True

This patch adds Manage/Unmanage of share servers in
Manila. It also updates the Manage Share API to accept
a "share_server_id" parameter, and updates Unmanage
of Share and Snapshots API to allow unmanaging of
shares and snapshots in DHSS=True.

Managed share servers are not deleted automatically
by manila, and if a single share is unmanaged in
DHSS=True, the respective share server will not be
deleted automatically as well.

Managing share servers require that the driver
implements 2 functions:
- get_share_server_network_info: obtain IPs from
  share server.
- manage_server: perform required operations to
  manage and return dict of backend_details.

Unmanaging share servers require that the driver
overrides unmanage_server function.

The IPs obtained from the backend are validated
by the Network plugin, so ports with the exact
IPs must exist in the subnet and admin subnet
associated with the share network specified
when managing the share server (unless
StandaloneNetworkPlugin is used).

It is recommended to rename the backend resource
if possible when managing the share server, to
prevent issues with re-managing a share server
that has already been managed.

This patch bumps the API microversion to 2.49.

APIImpact
DocImpact

Depends-On: I17c74b2aa242918188eeff368232c762a4b31093
Partially-implements: bp manage-unmanage-with-share-servers
Change-Id: I108961e7436ba13550ef2b8f02079c6e599a6166

commit_message:
Only run bandit when changing python content

This changes the gate check for bandit to only run when either python
or templated python files are edited. This will cause the check
to only be ran when those specific file types are edited, and to
skip the check when not needed.

Change-Id: I149ef6827ca10e32492f2b05beb8a13af5a03fc5

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-27 15:37:06.000000000', 'message': 'Increase default logging

The current helm chart defaults drops logs of any warnings
(and above) for anything logger outside of the namespace
of the deployed chart.

This is a problem, as logging could reveal important operator
information. While this could be done with a value override, there
is no reason to hide warning, errors, or critical information that
are happening in the cycle of the operation of the software
deployed with the helm charts. For example, nothing would get
logged in oslo_service, which is a very important part of running
OpenStack.

This fixes it by logging to stdout all the warnings (and above)
for OpenStack apps.

Change-Id: I16f77f4cc64caf21b21c8519e6da34eaf5d31498
'}, {'created': '2019-02-27 16:18:49.000000000', 'message': 'Increase default logging

are happening in the cycle of the operation of the software
deployed with the helm charts. For example, nothing would get
logged in oslo_service, which is a very important part of running
OpenStack.

This fixes it by logging to stdout all the warnings (and above)
for OpenStack apps.

Change-Id: I16f77f4cc64caf21b21c8519e6da34eaf5d31498
'}, {'created': '2019-02-28 09:53:01.000000000', 'message': 'Increase default logging

The current helm chart defaults drops logs of any warnings
(and above) for any logger outside of the namespace
of the deployed chart.

This is a problem, as logging could reveal important information for
operators. While this could be done with a value override, there
is no reason to hide warning, errors, or critical information that
are happening in the cycle of the operation of the software
deployed with the helm charts. For example, nothing would get
logged in oslo_service, which is a very important part of running

This fixes it by logging to stdout all the warnings (and above)
for OpenStack apps.

Change-Id: I16f77f4cc64caf21b21c8519e6da34eaf5d31498
'}]
commit_message:
Increase default logging

The current helm chart defaults drops logs of any warnings
(and above) for any logger outside of the namespace
of the deployed chart.

This is a problem, as logging could reveal important information for
operators. While this could be done with a value override, there
is no reason to hide warning, errors, or critical information that
are happening in the cycle of the operation of the software
deployed with the helm charts. For example, nothing would get
logged in oslo_service, which is a very important part of running
OpenStack.

This fixes it by logging to stdout all the warnings (and above)
for OpenStack apps.

Change-Id: I16f77f4cc64caf21b21c8519e6da34eaf5d31498

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-01 01:08:57.000000000', 'message': 'JSON ingester API execution feature

Operator can define an _exec_api view/table in any schema, including
the columns: endpoint, path, method, body, parameters, headers
(body, parameters, headers may be null).

Each time JSON ingester updates state, Congress will make all the
API requests as specified in these _exec_api views/tables.

The existing action execution semantics is used: execute any new
actions not present as of the last time the execution tables are
checked.

Each JsonIngester instance now keeps a reference to the shared
ExecApiManager instance. Each time a JsonIngester instance updates
state, it tells the ExecApiManager instance to check and execute API
requests.

partially-implements: bp json-data-model
Change-Id: I548b4d097452b2f001efc054780be29eb3a73398

commit_message:
JSON ingester API execution feature

Operator can define an _exec_api view/table in any schema, including
the columns: endpoint, path, method, body, parameters, headers
(body, parameters, headers may be null).

Each time JSON ingester updates state, Congress will make all the
API requests as specified in these _exec_api views/tables.

The existing action execution semantics is used: execute any new
actions not present as of the last time the execution tables are
checked.

Each JsonIngester instance now keeps a reference to the shared
ExecApiManager instance. Each time a JsonIngester instance updates
state, it tells the ExecApiManager instance to check and execute API
requests.

partially-implements: bp json-data-model
Change-Id: I548b4d097452b2f001efc054780be29eb3a73398

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-07 16:18:19.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that allocated PF matches the used PF

A neutron port can be created with sriov vnic type and also it can have
bandwidth resource request at the same time. In this case placement will
offer allocation candidates that could fulfill the bw request, then the
nova scheduler's PciPassthroughFilter checks if a PCI device is available
for such request. This check is only based on the physnet of the neutron
port and the physnet tag in the pci whitelist config. But it does not
consider that which PF provides the bandwidth.

The currently unsupported case is when a single compute node has more
than one PFs that are connected to the same physnet. This two PFs can have
totally different bandwidth inventories in placement. (E.g. PF1 has
plenty of bandwidth available and PF2 has no bandwidth configured at all).

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter migth accept the host simply
because PF2 still has available VFs even if the bandwidtht from the port
is fulfilled from PF1 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the PciClaim has the same logic as the Filter so it will claim
the VF from PF2 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF1 in placement.

TODO:
 * RPs are named after the device name, PCI request are identified by
   PCI address. We need to be able to map between the two to know that
   what PCI device can be selected based on the RP uuid that provides
   the bandwidth.
 * Use a more generic base class for the functional test as the current
   one creates an unnecessary ovs RP tree and we anyhow need to add more
   sriov device RPs to placement.
 * Make the functional test show the missing mapping logic in
 * PciPassthroughFilter and in PciClaim
 * Add the missing logic :)

Change-Id: I038867c4094d79ae4a20615ab9c9f9e38fcc2e0a

Change-Id: I038867c4094d79ae4a20615ab9c9f9e38fcc2e0a
"}, {'created': '2018-12-10 13:20:00.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that allocated PF matches the used PF

A neutron port can be created with sriov vnic type and also it can have
bandwidth resource request at the same time. In this case placement will
offer allocation candidates that could fulfill the bw request, then the
nova scheduler's PciPassthroughFilter checks if a PCI device is available
for such request. This check is only based on the physnet of the neutron
port and the physnet tag in the pci whitelist config. But it does not
consider that which PF provides the bandwidth.

The currently unsupported case is when a single compute node has more
than one PFs that are connected to the same physnet. This two PFs can have
totally different bandwidth inventories in placement. (E.g. PF2 has
plenty of bandwidth available and PF3 has no bandwidth configured at all).

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter migth accept the host simply
because PF3 still has available VFs even if the bandwidth from the port
is fulfilled from PF2 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the PciClaim has the same logic as the Filter so it will claim
the VF from PF3 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF2 in placement.

This patch adds a functional test case to that shows the failure in the
above use case.

TODO:
 * add the missing logic in PciClaim
 * add the missing logic if PciPassthroughFilter
 * device RPs are named after the device name, PCI request are identified by
   PCI address. We need to be able to map between the two to know that
   what PCI device can be selected based on the RP uuid that provides
   the bandwidth.

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I038867c4094d79ae4a20615ab9c9f9e38fcc2e0a

      PF where bandwdith is not available

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

"}, {'created': '2018-12-14 14:36:54.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that allocated PF matches the used PF

A neutron port can be created with sriov vnic type and also it can have
bandwidth resource request at the same time. In this case placement will
offer allocation candidates that could fulfill the bw request, then the
nova scheduler's PciPassthroughFilter checks if a PCI device is available
for such request. This check is only based on the physnet of the neutron
port and the physnet tag in the pci whitelist config. But it does not
consider that which PF provides the bandwidth.

The currently unsupported case is when a single compute node has more
than one PFs that are connected to the same physnet. This two PFs can have
totally different bandwidth inventories in placement. (E.g. PF2 has
plenty of bandwidth available and PF3 has no bandwidth configured at all).

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter migth accept the host simply
because PF3 still has available VFs even if the bandwidth from the port
is fulfilled from PF2 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the PciClaim has the same logic as the Filter so it will claim
the VF from PF3 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF2 in placement.

This patch adds a functional test case to that shows the failure in the
above use case.

TODO:
  * split up the patch to smaller pieces (object change, conf change,
    manager change)
  * refactor manager code to smaller functions
  * document the new pci whitelist flag
  * add functional test
    * sriov port without bandwidth works
    * bandwidth available in one PF but VF available only on the other
      PF where bandwdith is not available
  * unit test coverage

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I038867c4094d79ae4a20615ab9c9f9e38fcc2e0a
"}, {'created': '2018-12-14 16:53:22.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that bandwidth and VF are from the same PF

A neutron port can be created with direct vnic type and also it can have
bandwidth resource request at the same time. In this case placement will
offer allocation candidates that could fulfill the bandwidth request, then
the nova scheduler's PciPassthroughFilter checks if a PCI device, a VF,
is available for such request. This check is only based on the physnet
of the neutron port and the physical_network tag in the
pci/passthrough_whitelist config. But it does not consider that which PF
provides the bandwidth.

The currently unsupported case is when a single compute node has
whitelisted VFs from more than one PFs which are connected to the same
physnet. This two PFs can have totally different bandwidth inventories
in placement. For example PF2 can havee plenty of bandwidth available
and PF3 has no bandwidth configured at all.

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter migth accept the host simply
because PF3 still has available VFs even if the bandwidth from the port
is fulfilled from PF2 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the pci claim has the same logic as the Filter so it will claim
the VF from PF3 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF2 in placement.

This patch does not try to solve the issue in the PciPassthroughFilter but
it does solves the issue in the pci claim. This means that after
successful scheduling the pci claim can still fail if bandwidth is
allocated from one PF but a VF is not available from that specific PF
any more. This will lead to re-schedule.

Making the PciPassthroughFilter smart enough is complicated because:
* The filters are not knowing about placement allocation candidates at
  all
* The filters are working per compute host not per allocation
  candidates. If there are two allocation candidates for the same host
  then nova will only try to filter for the first one. [1][2]

This patch applies the following logic:

The compute manager checks the InstancePCIRequest ovos in a given
boot request and maps each of them to the neutron port that requested
the PCI device. Then it maps the neutron port to the physical device
RP in the placement allocation made for this server. Then the spec in
the  InstancePCIRequest is extended with the interface name of the PF
from where the bandwidth was allocated from based on the name of the
device RP. Then the pci claim will enforce that the PF interface
name in the request matches the interface name of the PF from where
the VF is selected from. The pci claim code knows about the PF
interface name of each available VF based on the value of the
``pf_interface_name`` tag in the pci/passthrough_whitelist config
option introduced in the previous patch.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L239
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L426

TODO:
  * refactor manager code to smaller functions
  * add functional test
    * sriov port without bandwidth works
    * bandwidth available in one PF but VF available only on the other
      PF where bandwdith is not available
  * unit test coverage

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

"}, {'created': '2019-01-24 16:21:55.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that bandwidth and VF are from the same PF

A neutron port can be created with direct vnic type and also it can have
bandwidth resource request at the same time. In this case placement will
offer allocation candidates that could fulfill the bandwidth request, then
the nova scheduler's PciPassthroughFilter checks if a PCI device, a VF,
is available for such request. This check is only based on the physnet
of the neutron port and the physical_network tag in the
pci/passthrough_whitelist config. But it does not consider that which PF
provides the bandwidth.

The currently unsupported case is when a single compute node has
whitelisted VFs from more than one PFs which are connected to the same
physnet. This two PFs can have totally different bandwidth inventories
in placement. For example PF2 can havee plenty of bandwidth available
and PF3 has no bandwidth configured at all.

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter migth accept the host simply
because PF3 still has available VFs even if the bandwidth from the port
is fulfilled from PF2 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the pci claim has the same logic as the Filter so it will claim
the VF from PF3 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF2 in placement.

This patch does not try to solve the issue in the PciPassthroughFilter but
it does solves the issue in the pci claim. This means that after
successful scheduling the pci claim can still fail if bandwidth is
allocated from one PF but a VF is not available from that specific PF
any more. This will lead to re-schedule.

Making the PciPassthroughFilter smart enough is complicated because:
* The filters are not knowing about placement allocation candidates at
  all
* The filters are working per compute host not per allocation
  candidates. If there are two allocation candidates for the same host
  then nova will only try to filter for the first one. [1][2]

This patch applies the following logic:

The compute manager checks the InstancePCIRequest ovos in a given
boot request and maps each of them to the neutron port that requested
the PCI device. Then it maps the neutron port to the physical device
RP in the placement allocation made for this server. Then the spec in
the  InstancePCIRequest is extended with the interface name of the PF
from where the bandwidth was allocated from based on the name of the
device RP. Then the pci claim will enforce that the PF interface
name in the request matches the interface name of the PF from where
the VF is selected from. The pci claim code knows about the PF
interface name of each available VF based on the value of the
``pf_interface_name`` tag in the pci/passthrough_whitelist config
option introduced in the previous patch.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L239
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L426

TODO:
  * add functional test
    * sriov port without bandwidth works
    * bandwidth available in one PF but VF available only on the other
      PF where bandwdith is not available
  * unit test coverage

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I038867c4094d79ae4a20615ab9c9f9e38fcc2e0a

This patch applies the following logic:

The compute manager checks the InstancePCIRequest ovos in a given
boot request and maps each of them to the neutron port that requested
the PCI device. Then it maps the neutron port to the physical device
RP in the placement allocation made for this server. Then the spec in
the  InstancePCIRequest is extended with the interface name of the PF
from where the bandwidth was allocated from based on the name of the
device RP. Then the pci claim will enforce that the PF interface
name in the request matches the interface name of the PF from where
the VF is selected from. The pci claim code knows about the PF
interface name of each available VF based on the value of the
``pf_interface_name`` tag in the pci/passthrough_whitelist config
option introduced in the previous patch.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L239
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L426

"}, {'created': '2019-02-12 16:06:04.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that bandwidth and VF are from the same PF

A neutron port can be created with direct vnic type and also it can have
bandwidth resource request at the same time. In this case placement will
offer allocation candidates that could fulfill the bandwidth request, then
the nova scheduler's PciPassthroughFilter checks if a PCI device, a VF,
is available for such request. This check is only based on the physnet
of the neutron port and the physical_network tag in the
pci/passthrough_whitelist config. But it does not consider that which PF
provides the bandwidth.

The currently unsupported case is when a single compute node has
whitelisted VFs from more than one PFs which are connected to the same
physnet. This two PFs can have totally different bandwidth inventories
in placement. For example PF2 can havee plenty of bandwidth available
and PF3 has no bandwidth configured at all.

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter migth accept the host simply
because PF3 still has available VFs even if the bandwidth from the port
is fulfilled from PF2 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the pci claim has the same logic as the Filter so it will claim
the VF from PF3 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF2 in placement.

This patch does not try to solve the issue in the PciPassthroughFilter but
it does solves the issue in the pci claim. This means that after
successful scheduling the pci claim can still fail if bandwidth is
allocated from one PF but a VF is not available from that specific PF
any more. This will lead to re-schedule.

Making the PciPassthroughFilter smart enough is complicated because:
* The filters are not knowing about placement allocation candidates at
  all
* The filters are working per compute host not per allocation
  candidates. If there are two allocation candidates for the same host
  then nova will only try to filter for the first one. [1][2]

This patch applies the following logic:

The compute manager checks the InstancePCIRequest ovos in a given

``pf_interface_name`` tag in the pci/passthrough_whitelist config
option introduced in the previous patch.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L239

from where the bandwidth was allocated from based on the name of the
device RP. Then the pci claim will enforce that the PF interface
name in the request matches the interface name of the PF from where
the VF is selected from. The pci claim code knows about the PF
interface name of each available VF based on the value of the
``pf_interface_name`` tag in the pci/passthrough_whitelist config
option introduced in the previous patch.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L239
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L426

"}, {'created': '2019-02-27 13:25:41.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that bandwidth and VF are from the same PF

A neutron port can be created with direct vnic type and also it can have
bandwidth resource request at the same time. In this case placement will
offer allocation candidates that could fulfill the bandwidth request, then
the nova scheduler's PciPassthroughFilter checks if a PCI device, a VF,
is available for such request. This check is only based on the physnet
of the neutron port and the physical_network tag in the
pci/passthrough_whitelist config. But it does not consider that which PF
provides the bandwidth.

The currently unsupported case is when a single compute node has
whitelisted VFs from more than one PFs which are connected to the same
physnet. This two PFs can have totally different bandwidth inventories
in placement. For example PF2 can havee plenty of bandwidth available
and PF3 has no bandwidth configured at all.

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter migth accept the host simply
because PF3 still has available VFs even if the bandwidth from the port
is fulfilled from PF2 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the pci claim has the same logic as the Filter so it will claim
the VF from PF3 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF2 in placement.

This patch does not try to solve the issue in the PciPassthroughFilter but
it does solves the issue in the pci claim. This means that after
successful scheduling the pci claim can still fail if bandwidth is
allocated from one PF but a VF is not available from that specific PF
any more. This will lead to re-schedule.

Making the PciPassthroughFilter smart enough is complicated because:
* The filters are not knowing about placement allocation candidates at
  all
* The filters are working per compute host not per allocation
  candidates. If there are two allocation candidates for the same host
  then nova will only try to filter for the first one. [1][2]

This patch applies the following logic:

The compute manager checks the InstancePCIRequest ovos in a given
boot request and maps each of them to the neutron port that requested
the PCI device. Then it maps the neutron port to the physical device
RP in the placement allocation made for this server. Then the spec in
the  InstancePCIRequest is extended with the interface name of the PF
from where the bandwidth was allocated from based on the name of the
device RP. Then the pci claim will enforce that the PF interface
name in the request matches the interface name of the PF from where
the VF is selected from. The pci claim code knows about the PF
interface name of each available VF based on the value of the
``pf_interface_name`` tag in the pci/passthrough_whitelist config
option introduced in the previous patch.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L239
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L426

any more. This will lead to re-schedule.

* The filters are not knowing about placement allocation candidates at
  all
* The filters are working per compute host not per allocation
  candidates. If there are two allocation candidates for the same host
  then nova will only try to filter for the first one. [1][2]

This patch applies the following logic:

The compute manager checks the InstancePCIRequest ovos in a given
boot request and maps each of them to the neutron port that requested
the PCI device. Then it maps the neutron port to the physical device

interface name of each available VF from the virt driver reporting the
'pf_interface_name' key as part of the return value of the
get_available_resource() driver call.

name informaton. Besides the libvirt driver the xenapi driver also
support SRIOV VF handling but this patch does not extend the xenapi
driver. So for the xenapi the above described configuration currently
kept unsupported.

whitelisted VFs from more than one PF which are connected to the same
physnet. These PFs can have totally different bandwidth inventories
in placement. For example PF2 can have plenty of bandwidth available
and PF3 has no bandwidth configured at all.

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter might accept the host simply
because PF3 still has available VFs even if the bandwidth from the port
is fulfilled from PF2 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the PCI claim has the same logic as the filter so it will claim
the VF from PF3 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF2 in placement.

This patch does not try to solve the issue in the PciPassthroughFilter but
it does solves the issue in the pci claim. This means that after
successful scheduling the pci claim can still fail if bandwidth is
allocated from one PF but a VF is not available from that specific PF
any more. This will lead to re-schedule.

* The filters are not knowing about placement allocation candidates at
  all
* The filters are working per compute host not per allocation
  candidates. If there are two allocation candidates for the same host
  then nova will only try to filter for the first one. [1][2]

The compute manager checks the InstancePCIRequest ovos in a given
boot request and maps each of them to the neutron port that requested
the PCI device. Then it maps the neutron port to the physical device
RP in the placement allocation made for this server. Then the spec in
the InstancePCIRequest is extended with the interface name of the PF
from where the bandwidth was allocated from based on the name of the
device RP. Then the PCI claim will enforce that the PF interface
name in the request matches the interface name of the PF from where
the VF is selected from. The PCI claim code knows about the PF
interface name of each available VF from the virt driver reporting the
'parent_ifname' key as part of the return value of the
get_available_resource() driver call.

The PCI claim process is not changed as it already enforces that
every fields from the request matches with the fields of the selected
device pool.

The current patch extends the libvirt driver to provider PF interface
name information. Besides the libvirt driver the xenapi driver also
support SRIOV VF handling but this patch does not extend the xenapi
driver. So for the xenapi the above described configuration currently
kept unsupported.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

boot request and maps each of them to the neutron port that requested
the PCI device. Then it maps the neutron port to the physical device
RP in the placement allocation made for this server. Then the spec in
the InstancePCIRequest is extended with the interface name of the PF
from where the bandwidth was allocated from based on the name of the
device RP. Then the PCI claim will enforce that the PF interface
name in the request matches the interface name of the PF from where
the VF is selected from. The PCI claim code knows about the PF
interface name of each available VF from the virt driver reporting the
'parent_ifname' key as part of the return value of the
get_available_resource() driver call.

The PCI claim process is not changed as it already enforces that
every fields from the request matches with the fields of the selected
device pool.

The current patch extends the libvirt driver to provider PF interface
name information. Besides the libvirt driver the xenapi driver also
support SRIOV VF handling but this patch does not extend the xenapi
driver. So for the xenapi the above described configuration currently
kept unsupported.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L239
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L426

commit_message:
Ensure that bandwidth and VF are from the same PF

A neutron port can be created with direct vnic type and also it can have
bandwidth resource request at the same time. In this case placement will
offer allocation candidates that could fulfill the bandwidth request, then
the nova scheduler's PciPassthroughFilter checks if a PCI device, a VF,
is available for such request. This check is based on the physnet
of the neutron port and the physical_network tag in the
pci/passthrough_whitelist config. It does not consider the actual PF
providing the bandwidth.

The currently unsupported case is when a single compute node has
whitelisted VFs from more than one PF which are connected to the same
physnet. These PFs can have totally different bandwidth inventories
in placement. For example PF2 can have plenty of bandwidth available
and PF3 has no bandwidth configured at all.

In this case the PciPassthroughFilter might accept the host simply
because PF3 still has available VFs even if the bandwidth from the port
is fulfilled from PF2 which in return might not have available VFs any
more.

Moreover the PCI claim has the same logic as the filter so it will claim
the VF from PF3 while the bandwidth was allocated from PF2 in placement.

This patch does not try to solve the issue in the PciPassthroughFilter but
it does solves the issue in the pci claim. This means that after
successful scheduling the pci claim can still fail if bandwidth is
allocated from one PF but a VF is not available from that specific PF
any more. This will lead to re-schedule.

Making the PciPassthroughFilter smart enough is complicated because:
* The filters are not knowing about placement allocation candidates at
  all
* The filters are working per compute host not per allocation
  candidates. If there are two allocation candidates for the same host
  then nova will only try to filter for the first one. [1][2]

This patch applies the following logic:

The compute manager checks the InstancePCIRequest ovos in a given
boot request and maps each of them to the neutron port that requested
the PCI device. Then it maps the neutron port to the physical device
RP in the placement allocation made for this server. Then the spec in
the InstancePCIRequest is extended with the interface name of the PF
from where the bandwidth was allocated from based on the name of the
device RP. Then the PCI claim will enforce that the PF interface
name in the request matches the interface name of the PF from where
the VF is selected from. The PCI claim code knows about the PF
interface name of each available VF from the virt driver reporting the
'parent_ifname' key as part of the return value of the
get_available_resource() driver call.

The PCI claim process is not changed as it already enforces that
every fields from the request matches with the fields of the selected
device pool.

The current patch extends the libvirt driver to provider PF interface
name information. Besides the libvirt driver the xenapi driver also
support SRIOV VF handling but this patch does not extend the xenapi
driver. So for the xenapi the above described configuration currently
kept unsupported.

I know that this feels complicated but it is necessary becase VFs has
not been counted as resources in placement yet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L239
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f6996903d2ef0fdb40135b506c83ed6517b28e19/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L426

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I038867c4094d79ae4a20615ab9c9f9e38fcc2e0a

We need to change from osh-infra to openstack
because ceph-openstack-config release runs in openstack namespace.

commit_message:
[CEPH] RGW tuning for Mimic release

Remove overrides that are already set or raised higher in the
Mimic release of Ceph for RGW.

rgw_thread_pool_size is now by default using 512
objecter_inflight_ops is now also set to 24576 by default for RGW

Change-Id: I982f6bc08954864afa5ad29923707e1bf64ba9fa

subject: Deep copy daemonset_yaml cross loop
messages:
[{'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-02-22 11:46:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-02-22 13:59:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-02-22 23:58:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Craig can you have a look at this.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-02-25 14:50:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

cheng, can you provide some example input to demonstrate this bug?'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-02-26 02:20:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

In each loop round, we cover every value set in previous loop round. So we don't meet issue. But the developers who maintain this file would have to be very careful, make sure every value set in each loop round. If someone doesn't set a value in a round, the value in previous round is used instead of the default value. 
In some case, developers need to write some strange code to cover the limits of no deep copy. For example, this line https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/blob/a5aeab344b36e2f0ea29ad931d79b143149bed79/helm-toolkit/templates/utils/_daemonset_overrides.tpl#L275 , we have to record __last_configmap_name for next loop round."}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-02-26 14:18:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@cheng li, shouldn't the same change be allied to the ./ceph-osd/templates/utils/_osd_daemonset_overrides.tpl?"}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-02-26 14:51:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Did not help me with the issue, although I'm not sure is this patch should solve it. I have been advised to try it.

Story: https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2005095"}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-03-05 15:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2019-03-06 03:04:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-22 11:46:46.000000000', 'message': 'Deep copy daemonset_yaml cross loop

In templates/utils/_daemonset_overrides.tpl,
$context.Values.__daemonset_yaml is used cross the loop. It is not deep
copied in each round of loop. It means that the property set in the
previous round of loop will still exist in current loop. This is not
expected.
This patch is to make a deep copy in each round of loop.

Change-Id: I4e610e4acf67d92257f9d254546ec0b5b31609fe
'}]
commit_message:
Deep copy daemonset_yaml cross loop

In templates/utils/_daemonset_overrides.tpl,
$context.Values.__daemonset_yaml is used cross the loop. It is not deep
copied in each round of loop. It means that the property set in the
previous round of loop will still exist in current loop. This is not
expected.
This patch is to make a deep copy in each round of loop.

Change-Id: I4e610e4acf67d92257f9d254546ec0b5b31609fe

commit_message:
Support per-host overrides of auto_bridge_add

.Values.network.auto_bridge_add is a global config. So in multi nodes
deployment, it requires that all hosts have the same nic names. This is
a strict limit.
This patch is to support per-host auto_bridge_add, so that we can define
different auto_bridge_add for hosts.
Also, this patch move .network.auto_bridge_add to .conf.auto_bridge_add

Change-Id: I4a4d6efbbfe073d035bc5c03700fbe998e708d0f
Story: 2005059
Task: 29601

commit_message:
(postgresql) set db admin password at startup

- Make the default to run the postgres database as the uid 999 which
  the default image maps to the 'postgres' user

- If the database is already initialized, before starting postgres
  set the 'postgres' database user password to match the declared
  intended password

Change-Id: I7b0ea7a86246b098f38ef4c03dd157731f61e066

    There are id,name and hosts fields in the response of list aggregates.
    So don't need invoke get_aggregate_detail again.

Change-Id: I94b768c2d3e0471ca619ce43387889ec74769ce2

    So don't need invoke get_aggregate_detail again.

commit_message:
improve _collect_aggregates

    There are id,name and hosts fields in the response of list aggregates.
    So don't need invoke get_aggregate_detail again.
    https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=#list-aggregates

Change-Id: I94b768c2d3e0471ca619ce43387889ec74769ce2

[{'created': '2019-02-28 08:46:06.000000000', 'message': "Add iptables -P FORWARD ACCEPT unit

On node reboot, kubelet and kube-proxy set
iptables -P FORWARD DROP which doesn't work with
flannel in the way we use it.
Add a systemd unit to set the rule to ACCEPT after
flannel,docker,kubelet,kube-proxy.

(cherry picked from commit e6b3325120a0ff333ebaea2db2d64e07d5011248)

commit_message:
Add iptables -P FORWARD ACCEPT unit

On node reboot, kubelet and kube-proxy set
iptables -P FORWARD DROP which doesn't work with
flannel in the way we use it.
Add a systemd unit to set the rule to ACCEPT after
flannel,docker,kubelet,kube-proxy.

Squashed in this patch, is the release notes patch [0]

[0] I07771f2c4711b0b86a53610517abdc3dad270574 which is
(cherry picked from commit e6b3325120a0ff333ebaea2db2d64e07d5011248)

Change-Id: I7f6200a4966fda1cc701749bf1f37ddc492390c5
Co-Authored-By: Spyros Trigazis <spyridon.trigazis@cern.ch>
(cherry picked from commit cf5f78e5be5ae5252c065700d581c36760897c3c)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-05 16:31:49.000000000', 'message': 'mini-mirror: Allow per-source Aptly config files

Current mini-mirror images are build using a single Aptly config file
provided at build time. In some cases, it may be desirable to provide an
Aptly configuration file for each source to change the behavior of a
single mirror. This commit introduces support for providing an Aptly
configuration file for each individual source. The config file should be
named aptly.conf and placed in the root source path.

Change-Id: Ic51fa2ab6898eaa14b45b67ba6708f2d7aea75eb
'}]
commit_message:
mini-mirror: Allow per-source Aptly config files

Current mini-mirror images are build using a single Aptly config file
provided at build time. In some cases, it may be desirable to provide an
Aptly configuration file for each source to change the behavior of a
single mirror. This commit introduces support for providing an Aptly
configuration file for each individual source. The config file should be
named aptly.conf and placed in the root source path.

Change-Id: Ic51fa2ab6898eaa14b45b67ba6708f2d7aea75eb

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-23 10:07:19.000000000', 'message': '[WIP]: Encrypt certs and keys

Octavia creates certificates and keys to manage encrypted
communication to amphorae.
When debug is enabled, the python taskflow module will log
all the information we provide to tasks (and sub-flows)
when we create amphorae or handle with anything related to
certificates and keys management (rotations, etc).

There are ways to tell taskflow to exclude specific things
from being logged (e.g., I136081045787c1bbe3ee846d5845a34201c57864).
While this handles some information in specific flows from being
logged, it is susceptive to code changes.

To avoid an everlasting whack-a-mole game, this patch will merely
encrypt sensitive information so we can safely log it and decrypts
it only when we need to use it.

Change-Id: I06d329ca53bc36bd27f7870ae7c7ca0cf18575b2

'}, {'created': '2019-01-03 14:28:40.000000000', 'message': 'Encrypt certs and keys

Octavia creates certificates and keys to manage encrypted
communication channel to amphorae.
When debug is enabled, the python taskflow module will log
all the information we provide to tasks (and sub-flows)
when we create amphorae or handle with anything related to
certificates and keys management (rotations, etc).

There are ways to tell taskflow to exclude specific things
from being logged (e.g., I136081045787c1bbe3ee846d5845a34201c57864).
While this handles some information in specific flows from being
logged, it is susceptive to code changes.

To avoid an everlasting whack-a-mole game, this patch will merely
encrypt sensitive information so we can safely log it and decrypts
it only when we need to use it.

Additionally, this patch also changes the default key passphrase
example to reflect a more secure standard that is used in Fernet.
The example passphrase is no longer hardcoded and can now be
modified in devstack settings.

commit_message:
Encrypt certs and keys

Octavia creates certificates and keys to manage encrypted
communication channel to amphorae.
When debug is enabled, the python taskflow module will log
all the information we provide to tasks (and sub-flows)
when we create amphorae or handle with anything related to
certificates and keys management (rotations, etc).

There are ways to tell taskflow to exclude specific things
from being logged (e.g., I136081045787c1bbe3ee846d5845a34201c57864).
While this handles some information in specific flows from being
logged, it is susceptive to code changes.

To avoid an everlasting whack-a-mole game, this patch will merely
encrypt sensitive information so we can safely log it and decrypts
it only when we need to use it.

Change-Id: I06d329ca53bc36bd27f7870ae7c7ca0cf18575b2

commit_message:
Supporting all py3 environments with tox

Converting environment py35 to py3 in tox.ini to show support
for all Python 3.x versions.

Also reordering list of template jobs.

Change-Id: Ic0da34ca8281a5634b9e224da4b16984bb76d18c

commit_message:
Support L7policy redirect http code

Currently, L7Policy already support the redirection by url_prefix.
Then we can support the redirection with HTTP code.

This patch adds an new option 'redirect_http_code' to L7Policy API.

Story: 2003609
Task: 24941
Change-Id: Id0c9c376ffbc2fb10ddb988537d0ef1a8205e586

[{'created': '2019-02-01 13:27:14.000000000', 'message': 'Switch integration tests to run with python3

'}, {'created': '2019-02-09 09:22:53.000000000', 'message': 'Switch integration tests to run with python3

Change-Id: I5c3078bdc66e33fe676d431bb28d92b35faaf479
'}, {'created': '2019-02-09 18:58:27.000000000', 'message': 'Switch integration tests to run with python3

__hash__() method is now defined in integration_tests.helpers.BaseTestCase
to avoid unhashable error during loading django test runner. This is
originally caused by the fact that the base testcase class for integration
tests is implemented on top of testtools and testtools does not define
__hash__() method. In Python 3, __hash__() method must be defined
if a class (re)defines __eq__() method to make the class hashable [1].
Ideally integration base TestCase class can be implemented on top of
Django test case, but the current implementation depends on features
from testtools a lot, so it seems better to add __hash__() method
as a workaround.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.5/reference/datamodel.html#object.__hash__

Change-Id: I5c3078bdc66e33fe676d431bb28d92b35faaf479
'}, {'created': '2019-02-09 18:59:58.000000000', 'message': "Switch integration tests to run with python3

tox env for the integration tests is now renamed to 'integration'
as it is no longer run under python 2.7.

originally caused by the fact that the base testcase class for integration

commit_message:
Switch integration tests to run with python3

tox env for the integration tests is now renamed to 'integration'
as it is no longer run under python 2.7.

__hash__() method is now defined in integration_tests.helpers.BaseTestCase
to avoid unhashable error during loading django test runner. This is
originally caused by the fact that the base testcase class for integration
tests is implemented on top of testtools and testtools does not define
__hash__() method. In Python 3, __hash__() method must be defined
if a class (re)defines __eq__() method to make the class hashable [1].
Ideally integration base TestCase class can be implemented on top of
Django test case, but the current implementation depends on features
from testtools a lot, so it seems better to add __hash__() method
as a workaround.

Unbound methods don't exist in Python 3[2], so six.create_unbound_method
doesn' work as expected. To dynamic method generation we have to use new
descriptors interface [3] or just generate new
functools.partialmethod [4] function introduced in Python 3.4 to
generate class methods with pre-defined 'path' argument and pass 'self'
as a first function argument for class instance.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.5/reference/datamodel.html#object.__hash__
[2] https://six.readthedocs.io/#six.create_unbound_method
[3] https://docs.python.org/3/howto/descriptor.html
[4] https://docs.python.org/3/library/functools.html#functools.partialmethod

Change-Id: I5c3078bdc66e33fe676d431bb28d92b35faaf479

commit_message:
ovsfw: Don't create rules if updated port doesn't exist

The firewall won't attempt on update to initialize port in case
port hasn't been initialized by sg_agent yet. This fixes a race where update
rpc call arrives between wiring tap device with integration bridge and
firewall initialization.

Change-Id: Ice0667df606ae23061acebceea23ab6e49dadbcf
Closes-bug: #1740885
(cherry picked from commit ed57c3de4241f94ead2bc7c7761bab99dd61894e)

messages:
[{'account_id': 29910, 'date': '2019-02-07 10:15:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-02-07 10:15:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2019-02-07 10:16:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-11 21:07:52.000000000', 'message': "correct the admin_or_target_domain rule

With the removal of KeystoneToken from the token model, we longer
have the ability to use the token data syntax in the policy rules.
This change broke backward compatibility for those is deploying
customized Keystone policies. Unfortunately, we can't go back
to KeystoneToken model as the change was tightly coupled with
the other refactored authorization functionalities.

Since the scope information is now available in the credential
dictionary, we can just make use of it instead. Those who have
custom policies must update their policy files accordingly.

Change-Id: I83eae5c390d720da05e91264519ae01e8ca32159
closes-bug: 1810983
(cherry picked from commit a2e307ed4d526e21cddf7551f160b587b89360e4)
"}]
commit_message:
correct the admin_or_target_domain rule

With the removal of KeystoneToken from the token model, we longer
have the ability to use the token data syntax in the policy rules.
This change broke backward compatibility for those is deploying
customized Keystone policies. Unfortunately, we can't go back
to KeystoneToken model as the change was tightly coupled with
the other refactored authorization functionalities.

Since the scope information is now available in the credential
dictionary, we can just make use of it instead. Those who have
custom policies must update their policy files accordingly.

Change-Id: I83eae5c390d720da05e91264519ae01e8ca32159
closes-bug: 1810983
(cherry picked from commit a2e307ed4d526e21cddf7551f160b587b89360e4)

commit_message:
Add --attached / --detached parameter to volume set

As to reflect cinder reset-state --attach-status functionality,
this patch adds --attached / --detached parameter to OSC's volume set
command.

Change-Id: Ic8ee928c9ab0e579512cfb7608f63bfcc2993c7b
Closes-Bug: #1745699

subject: Fix pep8 errors in os-ken
messages: [{'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-03-05 20:39:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2019-03-05 23:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-03-06 00:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-05 20:39:01.000000000', 'message': 'Fix pep8 errors in os-ken

Update the lower constraint for appdirs, similarly to how it has been
done in other repos.

Whitelist pep8 error E113.  This is the "unexpected indent" error.  This
module uses C-style comment blocks pervasively, things like:

    OFPP_IN_PORT = 0xfff8   # Send the packet out the input port. This
                            # virtual port must be explicitly used
                            # in order to send back out of the input
                            # port.
    OFPP_TABLE = 0xfff9     # Perform actions in flow table.
                            # NB: This can only be the destination
                            # port for packet-out messages.
    OFPP_NORMAL = 0xfffa    # Process with normal L2/L3 switching.

For the lines above the ones that have an indented comment with no code
to the left would get E113 with a recent change to a less permissive
policy.  It would cause over 260 changes to comment strings, destroying
the consistency of comment style, to make that change.  Therefore,
blacklist that pycodestyle error.

Change-Id: I6d2f463b50551f32bce863aa7dc0c70ad3054cbd
Story: #2005142
'}]
commit_message:
Fix pep8 errors in os-ken

Update the lower constraint for appdirs, similarly to how it has been
done in other repos.

Whitelist pep8 error E113.  This is the "unexpected indent" error.  This
module uses C-style comment blocks pervasively, things like:

    OFPP_IN_PORT = 0xfff8   # Send the packet out the input port. This
                            # virtual port must be explicitly used
                            # in order to send back out of the input
                            # port.
    OFPP_TABLE = 0xfff9     # Perform actions in flow table.
                            # NB: This can only be the destination
                            # port for packet-out messages.
    OFPP_NORMAL = 0xfffa    # Process with normal L2/L3 switching.

For the lines above the ones that have an indented comment with no code
to the left would get E113 with a recent change to a less permissive
policy.  It would cause over 260 changes to comment strings, destroying
the consistency of comment style, to make that change.  Therefore,
blacklist that pycodestyle error.

Change-Id: I6d2f463b50551f32bce863aa7dc0c70ad3054cbd
Story: #2005142

commit_message:
Setup Train PTL election

  Setting PTL Election
  Release is at: 2019-04-10
  Latest possible completion is at: 2019-03-20
  Moving back to Tuesday: 2019-03-19
  PTL Election from 2019-03-12T23:45 to 2019-03-19T23:45
  PTL Nominations from 2019-03-05T23:45 to 2019-03-12T23:45
  Set email_deadline to 2019-02-22T00:00
  Setting PTL timeframe end to email_deadline
  Begining of Rocky Cycle @ 2018-02-09 00:00:00+00:00
  End of Stein cycle @ 2019-03-05 00:00:00+00:00
  Election timeframe: 389 days, 0:00:00s

Note we do NOT alter the email_deadline so we can leverage the rolls
generated during the TC election.

Change-Id: I2596102a6af02a17899b71e086f402c3d01d3c99

commit_message:
Inline Consumer.increment_generation()

Consumer.increment_generation() was previously a thin wrapper around a
module-level _increment_consumer_generation method. With this patch, we
inline that method. In so doing, we remove a @writer decorator; but the
one place this was being called from was already wrapped in a @writer.

Change-Id: I32240fa6fefd9f431db59a656af000df95f146b6

[{'created': '2019-02-13 20:27:58.000000000', 'message': 'Use liberasurecode_get_version()

... to determine whether we have a supported version. Note that this
was introduced in libec 1.4.0, so increase our minimum supported
version, too.

Change-Id: I5f81ddd6df1970bef3a2614126bce0eb78f44473
Closes-Bug: 1780320
'}, {'created': '2019-02-13 22:27:23.000000000', 'message': "Use liberasurecode_get_version()

... to determine whether we have a supported version. If not
available, fall back to file name parsing to check the version,
keeping in mind that we haven't yet released a v2.

Change-Id: I5f81ddd6df1970bef3a2614126bce0eb78f44473
Closes-Bug: 1780320
"}, {'created': '2019-02-13 22:38:46.000000000', 'message': "Use liberasurecode_get_version()

... to determine whether we have a supported version. If not
available, fall back to file name parsing to check the version,
keeping in mind that we haven't yet released a v2.

Change-Id: I5f81ddd6df1970bef3a2614126bce0eb78f44473
Closes-Bug: 1780320
"}]
commit_message:
Use liberasurecode_get_version()

... to determine whether we have a supported version. If not
available, fall back to file name parsing to check the version,
keeping in mind that we haven't yet released a v2.

Change-Id: I5f81ddd6df1970bef3a2614126bce0eb78f44473
Closes-Bug: 1780320

releases required for single deployment of ceph cluster

upgrade: Fix pike to queens upgrade

apt.version_compare changed behaviour to return >= 1 in the event
that a newer package version is detected.

Resync charmhelpers code to pickup fixes for openstack upgrade
detection.

commit_message:
upgrade: Fix pike to queens upgrade

apt.version_compare changed behaviour to return >= 1 in the event
that a newer package version is detected.

Resync charmhelpers code to pickup fixes for openstack upgrade
detection.
